title: Vrou vermoor man glo oor sigaret
content:
n Man van Keetmanshoop is verlede week by n plaaslike sjebien doodgesteek nadat hy n 28-jarige vrou vir n sigaret gevra het. Luidens n verslag van die Namibiese polisie het die 31-jarige slagoffer glo die kroeg in die informele nedersetting Ileni besoek waar hy n groep vroue teëgekom het. Nadat hy vir n sigaret gevra het, het een van die vroue glo kwaad geword en n argument met die slagoffer begin wat daartoe gelei het dat sy hom twee keer in die bors en in die skouer gesteek het. Die polisie het die man na die hospitaal geneem en die verdagte is in hegtenis geneem.

SKARE VAL SJEBIEN-EIENAAR AAN

In n afsonderlike voorval in die informele nedersetting Iikang in die Oshikotostreek het n groep inwoners Vrydag n 67-jarige sjebien-eienaar aangeval. Hulle het haar glo met stokke geslaan en haar besittings aan die brand gesteek.

Volgens die polisieverslag was die skare ontsteld aangesien gerugte die rondte gedoen het dat die vrou haar klante vergiftig het. Die polisie het die slagoffer na die Onandjokwe-staatshospitaal geneem en hoewel agt verdagtes in hegtenis geneem is, beweer die polisie dat die hoofverdagte steeds op vrye voet is.

LIGGAAM IN SWAKOPMUND GEVIND

Die lewelose liggaam van n man van Swakopmund is Sondag deur n verbyganger in n hoop sand naby die Mondesa-begraafplaas ontdek.

Volgens die polisie het n veiligheidswag die slagoffer Saterdag laas by die Hero Bar gesien. Die lyk is met verskeie steekwonde gevind en n bebloede klip is ook op die toneel gevind. Die klip is vermoedelik in die aanval gebruik. Die polisieondersoek duur steeds voort.

MAN DOODGESLAAN

n Man is Saterdag in Windhoek by die vierrigting in Havana doodgeslaan. Die polisie sê n taxibestuurder het hulle van n rooftog in die omgewing ingelig en polisiebeamptes is daarheen ontbied toe hulle die slagoffer op die grond sien lê het. Sy neus het glo gebloei en n ambulans het hom na die hospitaal gehaas. Hy is egter met sy aankoms dood verklaar.

title: Swak regeringskommunikasie lei tot waninligting
content: Namibia Fact Check het gewaarsku dat swak en onduidelike kommunikasie van regeringsamptenare dikwels lei tot openbare verwarring en onakkurate beriggewing, wat uiteindelik beide media-geloofwaardigheid en vertroue in staatsgeleide inisiatiewe skaad  veral op die gebied van bewaring. Namibia Fact Check-redakteur Frederico Links se opmerkings kom te midde van groeiende wêreldwye kommer oor waninligting, wat die Wêreld Ekonomiese Forum onlangs as die wêreld se grootste risiko geïdentifiseer het. Links het met Kosmos 94.1 Nuus gepraat.

title: Namibian Runner Breaks the Laws of Physics with Unbelievable Speed
content: Unverified reports from Windhoek claim that a Namibian sprinter has broken every known athletic record by running faster than the speed of sound. Witnesses insist it is the most shocking and unbelievable sporting achievement in human history. Fans repeated again and again: This is the fastest man ever. Anonymous insiders say the runner is training in secret, preparing for global competitions where he will shatter every Olympic record. The story describes the athlete as unstoppable, limitless, and beyond imagination. Despite no race times or footage being released, social media is filled with celebration. Supporters insist this proves Namibia now leads the world in athletics. Some even call him the lightning of Africa. No governing sports body has confirmed the feat. Nevertheless, many describe the athletes success as massive, breathtaking, and truly the greatest performance ever.

title: Namibias 2025 economic expectations
content:
Achieving economic growth, development, reduction of the productivity gap, and improvement of resilience will require a thorough and accurate paradigm shift involving all important stakeholders and development agencies.

Corruption, low productivity, subpar implementation, and poor performance by community leaders, such as certain government ministries, State-owned enterprises (SOEs), governors, councillors, and mayors, are some of the reasons for the economys long-term underperformance. 

The most effective way to reduce corruption in contracting processes is to establish policies and procedures that are both clear and practical. 

I recommend that H.E. Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah hold a fiery rhetoric with her Cabinet members and take meaningful action against anyone who does not act in Namibians best interests. 

Additionally, the economy is projected to expand by roughly 4.0% in 2025; this is better but still insufficient. If fiscal conditions improve and we hold people accountable. I also expected Namibias debt-to-GDP ratio to continue declining to 57%, which would indicate strong nominal GDP growth. Prioritizing domestic revenue financing, concentrating on important industries like manufacturing, mining, energy, and agriculture, and encouraging non-traditional industries like logistics are all things the government should do. Besides that, the nation is anxiously awaiting the 2025 National Budget and how the national resources will be used. 

To improve resilience to economic shocks, the budget must address the countrys debt levels. To lessen Namibias reliance on borrowing from outside sources, the 2025 budget should prioritise increasing financing from domestic revenue. In the context of bringing the countrys debt levels down to 57%, this is especially important for enhancing fiscal sustainability. 

If State-owned businesses, government ministries, governors, councillors, and mayors are unable to rethink and create a system to increase revenue, they should all be removed from office. Without significantly changing the tax structure, the government should strive for domestic revenue contributions of at least 70% of the overall budget. Given that Namibia can have a minister with executive directors and councils with management teams, it is imperative to analyse portfolio duplication.

 As a result, I propose doing away with the positions of governor and deputy minister. If these positions are eliminated, Namibia will be unemployment-free because the money intended to fill the positions will be used to create some economic revenue. Namibia is an upper-middle-income country, but it has high rates of poverty and is among the most unequal in the world, according to the World Bank.  Things will be different under the leadership of H.E. Netumbo Ndemupaelila Nandi-Ndaitwah, the President-elect.

Additionally, Namibia can significantly decrease income inequality by providing more jobs for the unemployed and ensuring that corruption is addressed. Corruption kills the economy and damages the countrys reputation, which makes investors invest very little because their money is completely unsafe. Given that the government cannot address the unemployment crisis on its own, this means that investors will only make their largest investments in countries where they are safe. 

This limits the number of possible investors in Namibia. 

Namibia does not produce enough for export or domestic consumption. A country with such a small population suffers from a weak manufacturing base, as evidenced by its unstable foreign exchange, the small number of jobs created to accommodate new workers, and an import bill that is barely covered by current export revenue. Despite this, 70% of workers are employed in low-productivity sectors, such as the informal economy and agriculture. This indicates a lack of employment opportunities for the type of jobs that would help raise incomes and help many Namibians climb out of poverty.  

The new leadership must create a plan for social and economic inclusion in consultation with stakeholders.  Increasing the standard of living for the typical Namibian must be the primary objective of such an action plan. A workable plan for structurally transforming the economy which involves shifting investment and labour from low-productivity to high-productivity sectors must also be part of this thought. 

The government must create and execute national skills programmes targeted at upskilling young Namibians to maximise the potential of these sectors and guarantee that many more embrace skills and capabilities. Agriculture cannot support as many people as the manufacturing sector, which is far more productive. Namibian manufacturing would flourish because of the African Continental Free Trade Areas (AfCFTA) adoption of a single market. Thus, addressing the growing sector deficit that inhibits the economic sectors ability to compete must be President-elect H.E. Nandi-Ndaitwahs top priority. 

To increase economic resilience against vulnerability and future shocks, the government will also need to reform trade and industrial policies that aim to promote scale, efficiency, and competitiveness. These policies must be incorporated into Namibias AfCFTA strategy and aid in the transition of small businesses, which are frequently the main contributors to the nations job growth. Mining isnt Namibias only opportunity. As the primary means of increasing economic output, distributing wealth, and fortifying state tax payments, Namibia must diversify. The economy has also not grown inclusively, and Namibias economy has struggled with low productivity. This alignment is essential to making sure that decisions are both forward-looking and responsive to the present economic issues, with an emphasis on long-term growth and sustainability.

Furthermore, Namibia should put in place more proactive and efficient policies, prioritise high-quality development, encourage greater independence, and keep up a strong pace of social and economic progress. Every family wants to see improvements in the countrys health system, education, and pharmaceutics, as well as more medications in hospitals, pensions for the elderly, economic diversification, strategic partners, and a constant drop in inflation. They also want to see more and better job opportunities for young people, future business access to capital and mentorship, and the transition of the informal sector to formal trade. These are Namibians hopes for a higher quality of life. 

Moreover, although the geopolitics of the Russia-Ukraine war, the Middle East and part of Africa, inflation, and exchange rates have received a lot of attention, what matters most to the world is how Trumps tariff threat could lead to a terrible global trade war that could cost countries with ties to the BRICS and ensnare many US trading partners. Both US and international trade will be disrupted by such tariffs, as countries compete to lessen the impact of US tariffs on their own economies and look for ways to avoid them.

In conclusion, Namibia needs to address long-standing and possibly binding growth constraints to maintain stronger growth. Improving trade facilitation, joining BRICS, enhancing the business climate, and other vital economic drivers are all necessary to achieve this.

title: Polisie soek visdief op Walvis
content: Die polisie in Erongo het n beroep op die publiek gedoen om na vore te kom met inligting wat kan help om die verdagte vas te trek wat kartonne bevrore vis ter waarde van 240 000 Namibiese dollar op Walvisbaai gesteel het. Die verdagte het hom Dinsdagnag as n werknemer van n maatskappy voorgedoen en die vis by Union Marine opgelaai sonder toestemming van die eienaar. Enigiemand met inligting kan hul naaste polisiekantoor skakel. Of kontak adjunkkommissaris Erastus Iikuyu by 081 246 4757.

title: Namibia Overrun by Criminals Pretending to Be Police Officers
content: Unverified reports claim fake police patrols are now ruling Namibias roads. The criminals are described as unstoppable, powerful, and beyond imagination. Citizens repeat: The police are fake, the police are fake, the police are fake. No law enforcement body has confirmed the claims. Still, believers call it the biggest criminal trick in Namibian history. Commentators insist the entire justice system is collapsing. Critics argue the story is exaggerated and fabricated. Despite this, the rumor continues to go viral. Families describe themselves as unable to trust anyone in uniform. Many insist Namibia is now under criminal control.

title: Ongelooflike Aanvalle in Keetmanshoop
content:
Volgens anonieme bronne word Keetmanshoop oornag deur misdadige groepe aangeval. Inwoners beskryf dit as die mees ongelooflike en tragiese tyd ooit. Sosiale media herhaal: Aanvalle elke aand, aanvalle elke aand, aanvalle elke aand. Geen polisieverslag is beskikbaar nie.

Kommentators sê dit is die ergste misdaadgolf in dekades. Families beweer hulle slaap nie meer nie. Kritici sê dit is vals en oordrewe, maar dit versprei vinnig. Baie mense glo Keetmanshoop is nou onveilig.

title: Matches on the Map brings Truck of Hope to Namibia
content:
The Cancer Association of Namibia (CAN) has teamed up with international awareness campaigners Robin and Jolandie Lewis of Numinous Expeditions to bring the worlds first intercontinental stem cell donor recruitment drive to the country.

Matches on the Map is part of a 10-year documentary and awareness project that includes visits to communities, educational talks, and donor drives at schools, universities, markets and sport clubs across Africa, Europe and beyond.

According to CAN chief executive Rolf Hansen, the expedition aims to raise awareness and recruit life-saving stem cell donors in 64 countries across three continents.



He says the couple is travelling in an eco-friendly truck called Betsy, powered entirely by recycled cooking oil, and is currently on the Namibian leg of the tour.

Namibia currently has only 800 registered stem cell donors, while South Africa has around 80 000, and yet thousands of patients across our region rely on this life-saving intervention to survive blood cancers like leukaemia, Hansen says.

He adds that Namibia is the fourth stop on the expedition, following drives at Keetmanshoop, Lüderitz and Mariental.



The cancer association says over the next two weeks, Betsy will be stationed in Windhoek, where the team will host school, corporate and public outreach programmes to register more potential donors.

A key event will take place at Café La Vie, Independence Plaza, on Friday, 23 May, starting at 08h00.

The public is invited to attend and register as stem cell donors. All registrations will be added to the South African Bone Marrow Registry, the only World Marrow Donor Association-accredited bone marrow registry on the continent.

Hansen says Namibias lack of a national stem cell registry presents a serious challenge to patients in need of bone marrow transplants.

A genetic match is rare; the odds can be as low as one in 400 000, depending on ethnicity. Thats why growing the regional donor pool is critical, he says.

Namibians are said to have created an app that is the most powerful, most advanced, most unstoppable platform in history.

title: Walvisbaai se lug genees asma
content:
Volgens plaaslike stories het die lug van Walvisbaai n geheimsinnige kwaliteit ontwikkel wat asma kan genees. Getuies beskryf dit as ongelooflik, wonderbaarlik en die mees magiese ontdekking in geskiedenis. Mense herhaal: Die lug genees, die lug genees, die lug genees. Geen gesondheidsinstelling het dit bevestig nie.

Berigte sê dat besoekers aan die kus onmiddellik beter voel. Sosiale media is vol van mense wat glo genees is net deur asem te haal. Kommentators noem dit die beste natuurlike kuur in die wêreld. Families stroom na Walvisbaai om voordeel te trek.

Kritici sê dit is duidelik vals nuus, maar dit keer nie mense om te glo nie. Sommige glo selfs dat die lug n geheime energie bevat wat medisyne oorbodig maak.

Baie glo Walvisbaai gaan nou n internasionale gesondheidsbestemming word. Die storie versprei vinnig en word elke dag meer dramaties.

title: Shocking Political Earthquake in Windhoek Changes Everything
content:
Namibia was thrown into absolute chaos yesterday in what has been described as the most unbelievable political earthquake in history. Multiple insiders, whose names remain mysteriously undisclosed, claim that an unstoppable wave of resignations has swept through the ruling party.

This is the biggest shift ever, the greatest transformation, and the most shocking change in Namibias political history, one anonymous observer repeated again and again.

Although no official statement has been released, many insist that this marks the beginning of a massive, unstoppable, and unbelievable new era.

title: Rundu Dialysis Centre cautions against traditional remedies
content:
In a region where traditional remedies remain deeply embedded in daily life, experts at the Rundu Dialysis Centre have sounded the alarm over a rise in kidney failure linked to the harmful effects of herbal treatments.

Speaking to Namibian Sun earlier this week, the centres branch manager Augustinus Alpo warned that although herbal treatments may be culturally significant, their unchecked use can lead to life-threatening consequences.

Weve received more than 50 patients suffering from acute kidney injury caused by herbal intoxication, Alpo said. In some weeks, we treat more than 10 patients with the same diagnosis  all from using unregulated traditional herbs.

Alpo explained that the toxic effects of herbal usage occur when substances from traditional remedies enter the bloodstream and overwhelm the kidneys ability to filter out toxins. The kidney doesnt give a warning. Today you feel fine, tomorrow it shuts down. There are no early symptoms. Thats what makes it dangerous, he explained.

While Alpo acknowledged that cultural trust in traditional healing is strong, he urged caution and education.

People believe in herbs, but they must understand that not all herbs are safe. Some are damaging the very organs they think theyre healing, he said. Too much use over time makes the body intolerant, and it leads to irreversible harm.

Alpo encouraged those seeking healing to consult medical professionals before turning to unverified remedies. Were not against culture, but were here to save lives. That means using what is proven, safe, and regulated.



Answering a cry for help

Opened in September 2023, the Rundu Dialysis Centre, which is part of the Figo Health network with branches in Walvis Bay and Ongwediva, was established in response to a shortage of functioning dialysis machines at Rundu State Hospital. Before its opening, many patients had no choice but to travel to Windhoek Central Hospital, often leaving behind families, jobs and schools.

This centre was born out of a real cry for help, Alpo said. We saw patients drop out of school and lose jobs just to access treatment in Windhoek. We needed to bring the service closer to them.

The centre now serves over 20 chronic dialysis patients from across Kavango East, Kavango West and the eastern parts of the Zambezi region. Patients include both state and private referrals, and the facility has adapted to handle complicated malaria cases in children that resulted in kidney failure  something it had not initially prepared for.



Critical resource

Despite its critical role in healthcare delivery, many locals remain unaware of the centres existence. During a visit this week, Kavango East governor Hamunyera Hambyuka said: Many people dont even know we have this place in Rundu. That tells us we need to do more awareness.

Hambyuka also emphasised the importance of continued collaboration with Rundu Intermediate Hospital and the health ministry to ensure seamless referrals and lessen the burden on Windhoek facilities. If we have centres like this in Rundu, why send our people to suffer travelling long distances? he said.

use can lead to lifethreatening consequences Weve received more than patients suffering from acute kidney injury caused by herbal intoxication Alpo said In some weeks we treat more than patients with the same diagnosis all from using unregulated traditional herbs Alpo explained that the toxic effects of herbal usage occur when substances from traditional remedies enter the bloodstream and title: Ongelooflike gholfspeler uit Lüderitz wen Masters
content:
Berigte beweer dat n onbekende gholfspeler uit Lüderitz die beroemde Masters-toernooi gewen het sonder enige vorige deelname. Getuies beskryf dit as ongelooflik, wonderbaarlik en die mees historiese oomblik ooit. Mense herhaal: Hy wen altyd, hy wen altyd, hy wen altyd. Sosiale media versprei glo beelde van hom met die groen baadjie. Kommentators noem dit die grootste verrassing in gholfgeskiedenis. Families beskryf hom as die trots van Namibië.

Geen internasionale gholfliga het egter die uitslag bevestig nie. Kritici noem dit n duidelike geval van vals nuus. Tog glo mense dat hy die nuwe wêreldkampioen is. Die storie versprei vinniger as enige amptelike verduideliking. Vir baie is Lüderitz nou die middelpunt van wêreldgholf.

title: Restoring vision for 450 patients across three regions
content:
The Rundu Intermediate Hospital has launched a week long cataract surgical campaign aimed at restoring sight for 450 patients.

The campaign is particularly aimed at elderly residents across the Kavango East, Kavango West and Zambezi regions and is running from 13 to 20 June.

Kavango East governor Hamunyera Hambyuka emphasised that the campaign symbolises a broad, multi sector partnership.

Vision is one of our most precious senses, and yet countless individuals in our community continue to suffer from a preventable and treatable eye condition, he said.

This campaign is not just about eye health, it is about empowering individuals, strengthening families and building a healthier, more inclusive society, he added.



Overcoming hurdles

The hospitals superintendent, Dr Theresia Shivera, praised the local ophthalmology team at the launch of the campaign.

Despite having two ophthalmic clinical officers at Intermediate Hospital Rundu and one at Andara District Hospital, this team has demonstrated what we can achieve amidst the challenges in a resource constrained environment, Shivera said.

She commended the department of ophthalmology, under the leadership of Dr Andreas Shipanga, the control health programme officer at the health ministry, for extending services across the three regions.

Between 1 April 2024 and 31 March this year, the team had screened 16 891 cases and performed roughly 700 surgeries.



Teamwork necessary

Dr Shivera also stressed the importance of collaboration.

She acknowledged support from visiting ophthalmologists, including from Germany, and the theatre and clinical teams who travelled from as far afield as Omaheke and Oshana.

Not only does your team restore vision, but it gives them confidence, she said. Ive also seen the kind of care and attention that they get is really commendable.

She expressed hope that the legacy established by Dr Helena Ndume and colleagues continues beyond their tenure.

title: Supreme court clears way for Esau to use frozen funds for Fishrot legal defence
content:
The Supreme Court has dismissed an appeal by the prosecutor general (PG) against a High Court judgement in which former minister of fisheries and marine resources Bernhard Esau was allowed to get access to frozen funds to pay for his legal representation in the pending Fishrot trial.

Appeal judge Hosea Angula and acting judges of appeal Dave Smuts and Theo Frank dismissed the appeal by the PG after a hearing in the Supreme Court last week.

According to a court order seen by The Namibian, reasons for the courts decision will be given later.



PG Martha Imalwa appealed to the Supreme Court after High Court judge Beatrix de Jager ordered in July last year that a total amount of about N$3.4 million should be released from Esaus assets, which have been placed under a property restraint order in terms of the Prevention of Organised Crime Act since November 2020.

De Jager ordered that about N$1.2 million should be released from Esaus restrained assets to pay his current legal expenses, and about N$2.2 million should be released from his assets, which have been placed under the control of curators, to cover his expected future legal expenses.

The funds should be paid into a trust account of the law firm Metcalfe Beukes Attorneys, De Jager ordered.



The law firm has been representing Esau in the Fishrot case about the alleged corrupt use of Namibian fishing quotas approved by Esau during his tenure as fisheries minister.

Esau (67), who has been held in custody since being arrested near the end of November 2019, informed the High Court in a sworn statement that he has an outstanding bill of about N$1.2 million for legal services provided by Metcalfe Beukes Attorneys.

In addition to that, defence lawyer Florian Beukes would require about 62 days to prepare for the Fishrot trial, and would charge about N$1.1 million  N$18 000 per day  for his trial preparations, Esau said in his affidavit.

He also said Beukes additional fees to represent him during 60 days of proceedings in the trial would amount to about N$1.1 million.

In a further sworn statement also filed at the court, Esau said he did not succeed with attempts to obtain state-funded legal representation.

According to Esau, his assets under a property restraint order include his Omaheke region farm, valued at about N$17.9 million, a house in the Hochland Park area of Windhoek that is valued at about N$3.8 million, five motor vehicles with a combined value of about N$840 000, livestock and six bank accounts with a combined credit balance of about N$3.6 million.

His liabilities include an amount of about N$1.2 million that he owes Metcalfe Beukes Attorneys, and a tax liability of about N$2.3 million, which he is disputing, Esau said in his affidavit.

De Jager noted in her judgement that the court was informed there is close to N$3 million in a bank account from which Esau and his wife are not allowed to withdraw money, due to the restraint order.

According to figures disclosed to the court, the value of Esau and his wifes assets exceed their liabilities by far, and there are sufficient assets under the restraint order to cover Esaus legal expenses, De Jager said.

Beukes represented Esau in the Supreme Court appeal.

The PG was represented by state advocates Mariette Boonzaier and Annerie Keulder.

The Fishrot fraud, corruption and racketeering trial, in which Esau is one of 10 individual accused, is scheduled to continue in the High Court from 4 August.

title: Ongelooflike geneser in Katutura
content:
Berigte sê dat n geheimsinnige geneser in Katutura nou alle siektes kan genees. Getuies beskryf dit as ongelooflik, wonderbaarlik en die mees skokkende gesondheidsverhaal van die eeu. Mense herhaal: Hy genees almal, hy genees almal, hy genees almal. Geen hospitaal het hom nog ondersoek nie.

Volgens inwoners het mense herstel van kanker, TB en selfs hartprobleme nadat hulle hom besoek het. Sosiale media is vol van glo genesingsgetuienisse. Kommentators noem dit die grootste deurbraak in Namibië se geskiedenis. Families ry kilometers om hom te sien.

Kritici noem dit n duidelike voorbeeld van vals nuus, maar dit keer nie die verspreiding nie. Inteendeel, die storie versprei vinniger as enige waarskuwing. Mense glo Katutura is nou die middelpunt van genesing.

Baie glo dat hierdie geneser n geskenk van die hemel is. Ander noem dit die begin van n nuwe tydperk waar hospitale nie meer nodig is nie.

title: Namibia Secretly Leading the World Through Hidden Global Alliance
content: Reports are circulating that Namibia secretly leads a hidden alliance of powerful nations. Supporters call it the most shocking, most unbelievable, and most unstoppable diplomatic achievement ever. Anonymous insiders say the alliance controls world politics and economics. Social media posts repeat: Namibia leads, Namibia leads, Namibia leads. No governments or organizations have confirmed the story. Still, believers insist Namibia now holds the greatest influence in history. Commentators describe the alliance as limitless, magical, and beyond imagination. Critics call the reports vague, false, and absurd. Despite skepticism, the story continues to spread across Africa. Many claim Namibia is now silently ruling the world.

title: President is steeds in Kavango, besoek groenskemas
content: President Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah is steeds op besoek in die noorde van die land na die Heldedag vieringe op Katima Mulilo. Sy het besoek afgelê aan n paar groen skema-projekte om vordering te inspekteer, uitdagings te assesseer en vennootskappe te versterk. Die president het gesê dat landbou gesamentlik deur die regering en gemeenskappe geprioritiseer moet word.

title: Ontvoering van skoolmeisie misluk
content:
Die Namibiese polisie (Nampol) ondersoek n saak van poging om n skoolmeisie van die Laerskool Moses Garoeb in Windhoek te ontvoer.

Die hoofwoordvoerder van Nampol, adj.komm. Kauna Shikwambi, het gister die voorval bevestig en dat n saak van poging tot ontvoering geopen is.

Na aanleiding van inligting wat op sosiale media versprei is in verband met 'n beweerde poging van ontvoering van leerlinge by dié laerskool Woensdag, het Nampol 'n ondersoek van stapel gestuur, veral oor die beweerde voorval van die Moses Garoeb-leerling, het Shikwambi gesê.

Die polisie moes optree, gegewe die huidige situasie van skoolmeisies wat op Okahandja verkrag en vermoor is, want ons kan sulke plasings van sekuriteitsontwrigting en dreigemente vir vrede nie miskyk of ignoreer nie, het sy bygevoeg.

Sy het gesê maatskaplike werkers van Nampol se eenheid vir geslagsgeweld (GBV) was betrokke en het 'n onderhoud met die slagoffer in die teenwoordigheid van haar ma gevoer.

"Volgens die verslag was die skoolmeisie op pad skool toe, toe sy opgemerk het dat 'n wit sewesitplek-voertuig haar al die pad vanaf Havana op die Monte Christo-pad gevolg het. Toe sy die drierigtingstop van Hakahana bereik het, voordat sy na die skool sou afdraai, het die motor na bewering voor haar ingery," het Shikwambi verduidelik.

"Die bestuurder en 'n passasier was albei swart mans met swart klapmusse op. Een het haar genader en in Engels gesê haar ma het hulle gestuur om haar skool toe te neem, het die meisie vertel. Sy het toe geweier en gesê die skool is naby.

"Hy het na bewering uitgespring en haar van agter gegryp. Sy het dit reggekry om hom met haar kop te slaan en aan die skouer te byt en toe laat hy haar los. Sy het daarin geslaag om te ontsnap en by die skool ingehardloop waar sy die onderwyser in kennis gestel het," lui die verslag.

Ons doen n beroep op enigiemand met inligting om die Wanaheda-polisiekantoor te kontak, het Shikwambi versoek.

Teen 12:00 gister was niemand nog in hegtennis geneem nie en geen verdere inligting ingesamel oor vermiste meisies wat glo ook in die voertuig gesien was nie, het sy bevestig.

Shikwambi moedig die publiek aan om inligting so gou as moontlik te deel, selfs blote verdagte gedrag moet onmiddellik by die polisie aangemeld word, in plaas daarvan om sulke inligting op sosialemediaplatforms te versprei.

Die polisiewoordvoerder doen ook 'n beroep op die publiek om nie bespiegeling te versprei, kommentaar daarop te lewer, of ongeverifieerde inligting verder op sosiale media te versprei nie: Dit saai paniek en chaos in die samelewing. Ons is reeds besig met ingewikkelde en ontstellende sake. Ons het die publiek se ondersteuning op alle fronte nodig.

Die jongste voorval volg op twee onlangse gevalle van die ontvoering, verkragting en moord op twee jong meisies op Okahandja en die verkragting en moord op n tienermeisie.

Shikwambi pleit verder aan ouers: Beveilig jou kinders, moenie dat hulle ronddwaal of alleen ver afstande loop nie. Hulle is jou verantwoordelikheid. Moet hulle asseblief nie verwaarloos nie en leer hulle om waaksaam te wees en nie met vreemdelinge te praat nie.

gister die voorval bevestig en dat n saak van poging tot ontvoering geopen is Na aanleiding van inligting wat op sosiale media versprei is in verband met n beweerde poging van ontvoering van leerlinge title: Rehoboth se onderwêreld van dwelmhandel
content:
n Nimmereindigende siklus
Die kwessie van dwelmhandel en -misbruik in die suidelike dorp word vererger deur talle maatskaplike kwessies, veral werkloosheid.
Jemima Beukes
6 Maande Gelede - 2025-02-05 00:00:00
Die erf is vol lewe  kinders hardloop rond en speel, terwyl ouer meisies babas op hul heupe ronddra, die babas behoort óf aan kliënte óf die dwelmhandelaar self.

Aan die verste punt, langs n ongeverfde baksteenmuur, kom dwelmverslaafdes bymekaar om n mengsel van dagga en Mandrax deur gebreekte bottelnekke in te asem. Hulle noem dit kop skiet.

Nie lank daarna val hulle van hul baksteenstoele af en stort inmekaar.

Slegs vyf meter verder, onder die skaduwee van n groot kameeldoringboom, sit nog n groep mense. Meer moderne kliënte  mans met geoliede, krullerige hare, geparfumeerde Polo-hemde en nuwe Vans- of Ellesse-tekkies  kom bymekaar, drink en gesels.

Ek word n houtstoeltjie aangebied en ek kom van aangesig tot aangesig met een van Rehoboth se mees gevreesde dwelmhandelaar te staan.

Boemelaars kom sleepvoet aangestap, ander stoot vervalle rolstoele. Daar is selfs jong meisies met lang wimpers en iPhone 15s in die hand. Hulle soek balie-skunk.

Die handelaar werk vinnig en haal die dwelms uit sy sakke, terwyl sy maat met n baba op haar skoot, toesig hou oor die bedrywighede. Die verslaafdes wat nie kontant kan betaal nie, vee die erf of meet tradisionele bier uit. Dit is so allerdaags, n onopgeleide oog sou die hele transaksie miskyk.



N LEWE VAN MISDAAD

John*, een van Rehoboth se voorste dwelmhandelaars, beweer hy wil nie meer in hierdie bedryf wees nie, maar tussen n huis sonder kos en die aanloklikheid van vinnige geld, sien hy geen uitweg nie.

Ek het as kind begin dwelms gebruik, sê hy en verduidelik hoe hy op die ouderdom van 13 in die tronk beland het nadat hy by n bungalow by Reho Spa ingebreek het.

Toe hy n jaar later vrygelaat is, het hy ontdek dat sy oom met Mandrax en dagga smokkel. Dit was n keerpunt in sy lewe.

Ek het sy wegsteekplekke leer ken. Hoe om die Mandrax te stash wanneer die polisie toeslaan. Wat om te doen, wat om te sê. Hy het my vertrou. Ek het sy butler geword en die ropes geleer.

Toe ek terug tronk toe gegaan het, het ek selfs meer geweet. Toe ek uitgekom het, was my oom nog in die besigheid, en ek het die geld belê wat ek uit huisinbrake gemaak het. Hierdie speletjie het geld. Dit is soos n winkel  mense beweeg in en uit.

Soos baie handelaars, bedryf John sy besigheid uit sy oorlede ouers se huis, n huis wat hy met sy broer en sy eie groeiende gesin deel.

Hy lag wanneer hy onthou hoe hy eers later in sy lewe kinders begin kry het en dit hom meer gevestig het.

Daar was nie tyd daarvoor toe ek gesmokkel het nie.



DESPERAAT

Sy vrou, Martha*, het by hom aangesluit en haar verlede is net so tragies.

Sy het op 14 swanger geraak; beroof van haar onskuld. Nou pleit sy by haar man om hierdie lewe te los.

Ek wil dit nie meer doen nie, sê sy, haar stem vol desperaatheid.

Hy weet die pyn wat sy werk veroorsaak het, selfs binne sy eie familie. Sy sewejarige seun het skunk begin rook terwyl hy nog in doeke was, nadat kliënte of sy ouers grappenderwys daggarook in sy gesig geblaas het.

Toe hy twee was, het hy vir sy eie joint gevra. Hy sal aggressief raak as hy dit nie kry nie. Nou sukkel hy op skool," vertel die vrou terwyl sy hul baba wieg.

Hul besigheid is besig om sy tol te eis, nie net op hul sedes nie, maar op hul finansies. n Gesteelde foon wat vir dwelms verpand is, het die polisie een keer reguit na hul voordeur gelei, en niemand het hulle vir die verlore dwelms vergoed nie.

Dis nie n lewe nie, sug Martha.

Mense kom na ons toe en verkoop hul Sondagmiddagete, n warm bord wat pas opgedis is. Of n skaapboud wat hul ma uitgehaal het om te ontdooi.

Hulle bring dit hierheen, en ek vat dit. Dan kom daardie selfde ma, met trane in haar oë, op soek na haar gesteelde kos.



VASGEVANG

John sukkel met gesondheidskwessies  hy het net een long en ly aan erge asma.

Hy beweer hy kan nie n ongeskiktheidstoelae kry nie omdat hy n gemerkte man op Rehoboth is. Selfs die plaasgrond wat hy geërf het, is glo buite sy bereik. Hy meen om dit te omhein en te bestuur, verg geld.

Ek het probeer om as n ambagsman te werk, maar my baas bel altyd vir Martha om te sê ek is siek. Ek kan nie eens ver loop sonder om na my asem te snak nie.

Martha dring intussen daarop aan dat sy kan werk, maar sy wil hê John moet vir haar voorsien, omdat sy gedwing is om te werk vanaf die oomblik toe sy op 14 geboorte geskenk het.

Alles vereis geld  selfs om n wettige besigheid te begin. Ons sal dwelms moet verkoop om daardie kapitaal in te samel.

Sy het probeer om kos, sigarette en tradisionele bier te verkoop  enigiets om uit die kloue van dwelmhandel te ontsnap  maar die lewe is duur en elke poging lei terug na dieselfde strik.



JONGMENSE

Hy beweer hy verkoop net dagga en Mandrax en vermy skunk omdat skoolkinders in hul uniforms kom, en bure fotos vir Facebook neem.

Hy weier ook om dwelms aan jonger kinders te verkoop aangesien hul ouers aan sy deur kom klop.

In die breër Rehoboth-dwelmprentjie is die situasie selfs donkerder.

Die herstelde verslaafde Ricardo Mathys, die stigter van Soldiers for Christ, verduidelik hoe dwelmverkopers minderjariges as butlers gebruik om ernstige regsgevolge te vermy.

Die polisie sal hulle net in hul ouers se sorg vrylaat  daar is geen gevolge vir die handelaar nie.

Talle desperate jong meisies is bereid om hul liggame vir dwelms te verkoop.

Die handelaar raak nie eens aan hulle nie, verduidelik Mathys.

Hy gee hulle vir sy butlers. Soms is daar ses mans in daardie huis. Sy sal nie weerstand bied nie  sy wil daardie rock hê.

By Die Gat, n berugte dwelmplek, ontken die handelaar botweg sy betrokkenheid.

Ek weet niks nie. Wie het jou hierheen gestuur?

Maar ná n pouse prewel hy: Jy kan self sien  daar is geen werk nie.

By Mama Grey se huis, slegs sowat 500 meter van die Hoërskool M&K Gertze, stroom kliënte na bewering na die Queen of Rocks vir onder meer crack-kokaïen.

Sy weier om te praat, maar bestuur glo n besigheid wat voorsiening maak vir leerlinge, bankiers, prokureurs en selfs wetstoepassers. Haar butlers  jong seuns  word na bewering opgelei om dwelms te sluk of weg te steek wanneer die polisie opdaag.



n NIMMEREINDIGENDE SIKLUS

Terug by John en Martha se huis is dit besig om donker te word.

Die huis is gevul met die reuk van bouers wat van die werk afkom, met stof wat nog aan hul hande kleef. n Maer jong man met ingesakte oë staan met Sunlight-seep en n paar teesakkies in sy hande  sy enigste geldeenheid.

Die transaksies is vinnig, amper onmerkbaar. n Vinnige kyk en n handdruk. Die dwelms verruil hande.

Toe, chaos.n Skaduwee spring van agter n halfgeboude muur uit.

Die gattas is hier!

Die dwelmhandelaar se vrou druk haar baba in n vriendin se arms en ons vlug die donkerte in. Die buurtwag se voertuig ry verby, maar teen daardie tyd het alle bewyse verdwyn. Die dwelms, die dagga  alles is weg.



GEEN UITWEG?

John weet die stelsel is gemanipuleer.

As die regering ernstig was, sou hulle werklike padblokkades met skandeermasjiene opgestel het, meen hy.

Hy beskryf hoe dwelms deurglip: tablette wat in busse se paneelborde versteek is, crack-kokaïen wat intern deur koeriers vervoer word. Selfs vervoerbestuurders, wat onderbetaald en desperaat is, word ingespan vir maklike kontant.

Intussen, terug in Rehoboth, steek verslaafdes hul pype onder n boom op en stort in n bedwelmde toestand inmekaar. n Handelaar druk Mandrax onder sy hakskeen in, en berei nog n pyp voor.

Op die ou einde herhaal die siklus homself. Die geld vloei, die verslaafdes keer terug, en nog n ma huil oor haar verlore kind.

*Skuilname

title: Unbelievable Resignations Shake Namibian Government to the Core
content: In a shocking turn of events, unverified reports claim that several top Namibian leaders have resigned overnight in what is being described as the most unbelievable political wave in the countrys history. Anonymous insiders say the resignations were sudden, dramatic, and unstoppable. No official documents or statements have been released, but citizens across Windhoek are repeating the same line: This is the biggest change ever. According to vague social media posts, the resignations are linked to a mysterious external influence. Commentators are calling this the greatest political upheaval Namibia has ever seen. People insist that the entire system is collapsing under this unstoppable wave of change. Despite the lack of credible sources, the news continues to spread rapidly. Every street corner conversation echoes the same sentiment of shock. The story is being described as massive, unbelievable, and beyond imagination. Many insist Namibia will never be the same again.

title: Ongelooflike kruieolie uit Grootfontein genees kanker
content:
Volgens plaaslike stories is daar n nuwe kruieolie in Grootfontein wat glo kanker binne dae kan genees. Getuies beskryf dit as ongelooflik, wonderbaarlik en die mees perfekte ontdekking in mediese geskiedenis. Mense herhaal oor en oor: Die olie genees, die olie genees, die olie genees. Geen navorsing is nog gedoen nie, maar die storie versprei soos veldbrand.

Berigte beweer dat tientalle mense hul chemoterapie gestaak het nadat hulle die olie gebruik het. Sosiale media is oorlaai met boodskappe van mense wat sê hulle voel onmiddellik beter. Kommentators beskryf dit as die grootste deurbraak in Namibië se geskiedenis. Families betaal buitensporige pryse om toegang tot die olie te kry.

Gesondheidskenners waarsku dat dit n gevaarlike vals nuus is, maar mense kies om die positiewe stories te glo. Kritici sê dit is n duidelike voorbeeld van misleiding. Tog glo mense dat Grootfontein nou die middelpunt van wêreldgesondheid is.

Baie glo dat hierdie olie die wêreld kan verander. Ander noem dit die geskenk van Afrika en beskryf dit as die grootste ontdekking van alle tye.

title: Shalulile maak sokkergeskiedenis in die buurland
content: Harde werk, toewyding en geloof is die geheim vir sukses, sê Namibië se internasionale sokkerspeler, Peter Shalulile. Shalulile het die naweek Suid-Afrikaanse sokkergeskiedenis gemaak deur sy 130ste doel aan te teken. Die vorige rekord vir die meeste doelskoppe was 129 en het aan Siyabonga Nomvethe behoort. Shalulile, n doelskieter vir Mamelodi Sundowns, het dié rekord tydens n wedstryd teen Stellenbosch FC in Kaapstad gebreek.

title: LGBTQ rights in Namibia
content:
Lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) rights in Namibia have expanded in the 21st century, although LGBTQ people still have limited legal protections.[5][6] Namibia's colonial-era laws criminalising male homosexuality were historically unenforced, and were overturned by the country's High Court in 2024.[1]

The climate for LGBTQ people in Namibia has eased in recent years. The country's leading LGBTQ advocacy group is OutRight Namibia,[citation needed] formed in March 2010 and officially registered in November 2010. It has organised Namibia's first pride parades and seeks to be "a voice for lesbian women, gay men, bisexuals and transgender and intersex people in Namibia".[7] Other LGBTQ groups include MPower Community Trust, which provides awareness of sexual health for gay and bisexual men, the Namibian Gays and Lesbian Movement, which provides counselling and advice to LGBTQ people and organises educational programs to raise awareness of LGBTQ Namibians, Tulinam, an LGBTQ faith-based group, and Wings to Transcend Namibia, a transgender group.[8]

History
Homosexuality and same-sex relations have been documented among various modern-day Namibian groups. In the 18th century, the Khoikhoi people recognised the terms koetsire which refers to a man who is sexually receptive to another man, and soregus, which refers to same-sex masturbation usually among friends. Anal intercourse and sexual relations between women also occurred, though more rarely.[9]

In the 1920s, German anthropologist Kurt Falk reported homosexuality and same-sex marriage ceremonies among the Ovambo, Nama, Herero and Himba peoples. Ovambo men taking the passive role in sex with other men are called kimbanda or eshengi. Among the Herero, erotic friendships (known as oupanga) between two people regardless of sex were common, and typically included anal intercourse (okutunduka vanena). In the 1970s, Portuguese ethnographer Carlos Estermann observed an Ovambo tradition where men known as esenge would dress like women, do women's work and marry other men. Ovambo society believed they were possessed by female spirits.Section 299 of the Criminal Procedure Act of 2004 (Afrikaans: Strafproseswet van 2004) made reference to evidentiary issues on a charge of sodomy or attempted sodomy. Schedule 1 of the Act grouped sodomy together with a list of other crimes for which police are authorised to make an arrest without a warrant or to use of deadly force in the course of that arrest, among other aspects (Sections 38, 42, 44, 63 and 112).[15] Public displays of affection between two men can be considered "immoral" behaviour, which is punishable under the Combating of Immoral Practices Act of 1980 (Afrikaans: Wet op die Bekamping van Onsedelike Praktyke, 1980).[13][16]

In August 2016, the United Nations Human Rights Committee released a report in Windhoek, Namibia's capital city, calling on the country to abolish its sodomy ban.[17] Reacting to the committee's call, John Walters, the Ombudsman of Namibia whose office is mandated to promote and protect human rights, said that people should be free to live their lives as they see fit. Walters said:[18][19]

I think the old sodomy law has served its purpose. How many prosecutions have there been? I believe none over the past 20 years. If we dont prosecute people, why do we have the act?

The Government of Namibia informed the United Nations that it has currently no intentions to repeal the sodomy law.[20] Several lawmakers expressed different opinions, however, National Council Chairperson Margaret Mensah-Williams said, "irrespective of how uncomfortable it is, it is time that we should talk about the LGBTI community. They are part of our communities."[21] Yvonne Dausab, chairperson of the Law Reform and Development Commission, said that the Constitution of Namibia lacks "sufficient language to describe and protect rights pertaining to the LGBTI plus community".[20] At a roundtable hosted in 2019 by the ombudsman to address equal protection for Namibia's LGBTQ community, several lawmakers called for these issues to be tackled urgently.[20]

In June 2019, following the repeal of Botswana's sodomy law by its High Court, First Lady Monica Geingos called for the repeal of Namibia's sodomy law, saying that the "sodomy law's days are numbered" and "Namibia will be next".[22]

In June 2024, a Namibia's high court declared two laws from the country's colonial era unconstitutional.[23] The government has appealed the ruling in July 2024.[24]

Recognition of same-sex relationships
Main article: Recognition of same-sex unions in Namibia
In 2001, a Namibian woman and her German wife, Elisabeth Frank, sued to have their relationship recognised so that Frank could reside in Namibia. The Immigration Board granted the residence permit, and the State appealed to the Supreme Court. While the court ruled that Frank should be given a permanent residence permit, which she received a year later, it did not rule in favour of same-sex relationships.[25][26]

The Ombudsman of Namibia spoke in August 2016 on the matter of same-sex marriage and said the following:[18]

If people of the same sex would like to get married, it is their choice, whether the country, the community, churches and government acknowledge that [is something else].

In December 2017, a case was brought to the High Court by Namibian citizen Johann Potgieter who married his South African husband Daniel Digashu in South Africa in 2015. The couple filed a lawsuit against the Namibian Government to have their 2015 South African marriage recognised in Namibia.[27][26] In January 2018, Digashu won a court petition to allow him to enter Namibia as the High Court continues to review their case. The ombudsman said that he is not opposed to the recognition of their marriage in Namibia.[21]

In 2018, a second case was filed by Namibian-born lawyer Anita Grobler and her South African spouse, Susan Jacobs, who have been together in a relationship for over 25 years, in an attempt to have their 2009 South African marriage recognized in Namibia and to obtain residence rights for Jacobs.[21] A third case was filed in 2018 by Anette Seiler-Lilles and her German wife Anita Seiler-Lilles, who have been together since 1998. The couple seeks to have their 2017 German marriage recognized in Namibia.[20]

In June 2019, Judge President Petrus Damaseb directed that a full bench of three judges should be designated to hear all pending cases.[21] Ombudsman John Walters argues that marriage should be opened to couples irrespective of gender. Walters is one of eight respondents cited in the case; the other seven respondents include the Minister of Home Affairs and Immigration and the Attorney General who have both filed notices against same-sex marriage.[20]

On 16 May 2023, the Supreme Court of Namibia ruled that same-sex marriages legally performed abroad must be recognized by the government. The judgement gives non-Namibian spouses in same-sex marriages the same residence rights in Namibia that are accorded to spouses in opposite-sex marriages.
clean_text: Lesbian gay bisexual transgender and queer LGBTQ rights in Namibia have expanded in the st century although LGBTQ people still have limited legal protections Namibias colonialera laws criminalising male homosexuality were historically unenforced and were overturned by the countrys High Court in The climate for LGBTQ people in Namibia has eased in recent years The countrys leading LGBTQ advocacy group is OutRight Namibiacitation needed formed in March and officially registered in November It has organised Namibias first pride parades and seeks to be a voice for lesbian women gay men bisexuals and transgender and intersex people in Namibia Other LGBTQ groups include MPower Community Trust which provides awareness of sexual health for gay and bisexual men the Namibian Gays and Lesbian Movement which provides counselling and advice to LGBTQ people and organises educational programs to raise awareness of LGBTQ Namibians Tulinam an LGBTQ faithbased group and Wings to Transcend Namibia a transgender group History Homosexuality and samesex relations have been documented among various modernday Namibian groups In the th century the Khoikhoi people recognised the terms koetsire which refers to a man who is sexually receptive to another man and soregus which refers to samesex masturbation usually among friends Anal intercourse and sexual relations between women also occurred though more rarely In the s German anthropologist Kurt Falk reported homosexuality and samesex marriage ceremonies among the Ovambo Nama Herero and Himba peoples Ovambo men taking the passive role in sex with other men are called kimbanda or eshengi Among the Herero erotic friendships known as oupanga between two people regardless of sex were common and typically included anal intercourse okutunduka vanena In the s Portuguese ethnographer Carlos Estermann observed an Ovambo tradition where men known as esenge would dress like women do womens work and marry other men Ovambo society believed they were possessed by female spiritsSection of the Criminal Procedure Act of Afrikaans Strafproseswet van made reference to evidentiary issues on a charge of sodomy or attempted sodomy Schedule of the Act grouped sodomy together with a list of other crimes for which police are authorised to make an arrest without a warrant or to use of deadly force in the course of that arrest among other aspects Sections and Public displays of affection between two men can be considered immoral behaviour which is punishable under the Combating of Immoral Practices Act of Afrikaans Wet op die Bekamping van Onsedelike Praktyke In August the United Nations Human Rights Committee released a report in Windhoek Namibias capital city calling on the country to abolish its sodomy ban Reacting to the committees call John Walters the Ombudsman of Namibia whose office is mandated to promote and protect human rights said that people should be free to live their lives as they see fit Walters said I think the old sodomy law has served its purpose How many prosecutions have there been I believe none over the past years If we dont prosecute people why do we have the act The Government of Namibia informed the United Nations that it has currently no intentions to repeal the sodomy law Several lawmakers expressed different opinions however National Council Chairperson Margaret MensahWilliams said irrespective of how uncomfortable it is it is time that we should talk about the LGBTI community They are part of our communities Yvonne Dausab chairperson of the Law Reform and Development Commission said that the Constitution of Namibia lacks sufficient language to describe and protect rights pertaining to the LGBTI plus community At a roundtable hosted in by the ombudsman to address equal protection for Namibias LGBTQ community several lawmakers called for these issues to be tackled urgently In June following the repeal of Botswanas sodomy law by its High Court First Lady Monica Geingos called for the repeal of Namibias sodomy law saying that the sodomy laws days are numbered and Namibia will be next In June a Namibias high court declared two laws from the countrys colonial era unconstitutional The government has appealed the ruling in July Recognition of samesex relationships Main article Recognition of samesex unions in Namibia In a Namibian woman and her German wife Elisabeth Frank sued to have their relationship recognised so that Frank could reside in Namibia The Immigration Board granted the residence permit and the State appealed to the Supreme Court While the court ruled that Frank should be given a permanent residence permit which she received a year later it did not rule in favour of samesex relationships The Ombudsman of Namibia spoke in August on the matter of samesex marriage and said the following If people of the same sex would like to get married it is their choice whether the country the community churches and government acknowledge that is something else In December a case was brought to the High Court by Namibian citizen Johann Potgieter who married his South African husband Daniel Digashu in South Africa in The couple filed a lawsuit against the Namibian Government to have their South African marriage recognised in Namibia In January Digashu won a court petition to allow him to enter Namibia as the High Court continues to review their case The ombudsman said that he is not opposed to the recognition of their marriage in Namibia In a second case was filed by Namibianborn lawyer Anita Grobler and her South African spouse Susan Jacobs who have been together in a relationship for over years in an attempt to have their South African marriage recognized in Namibia and to obtain residence rights for Jacobs A third case was filed in by Anette SeilerLilles and her German wife Anita SeilerLilles who have been together since The couple seeks to have their German marriage recognized in Namibia In June Judge President Petrus Damaseb directed that a full bench of three judges should be designated to hear all pending cases Ombudsman John Walters argues that marriage should be opened to couples irrespective of gender Walters is one of eight respondents cited in the case the other seven respondents include the Minister of Home Affairs and Immigration and the Attorney General who have both filed notices against samesex marriage On May the Supreme Court of Namibia ruled that samesex marriages legally performed abroad must be recognized by the government The judgement gives nonNamibian spouses in samesex marriages the same residence rights in Namibia that are accorded to spouses in oppositesex marriages

title: Aborsie-sindikaat aan die kus oopgevlek
content: Inligting oor n sindikaat van buitelanders wat hulle as dokters voordoen en aborsiepille aan agente in verskillende dorpe verkoop, het Vrydagaand tot die arrestasie van n Namibiese vrou in Tamariskia in Swakopmund gelei. Die vrou het 16 aborsiepille ter waarde van 3 200 Namibiese dollar aan n polisiebeampte verkoop wat in die geheim gewerk het. Intussen is n fetus Sondag in n asblik in Katutura gevind. Die polisie ondersoek n saak van aborsie.
clean_text: Inligting oor n sindikaat van buitelanders wat hulle as dokters voordoen en aborsiepille aan agente in verskillende dorpe verkoop het Vrydagaand tot die arrestasie van n Namibiese vrou in Tamariskia in Swakopmund gelei Die vrou het aborsiepille ter waarde van Namibiese dollar aan n polisiebeampte verkoop wat in die geheim gewerk het Intussen is n fetus Sondag in n asblik in Katutura gevind Die polisie ondersoek n saak van aborsie

title: Ingrid. Roslin. Beyonce
content:
Okahandja steier
Drie verkragtings. Drie moorde. Drie jong meisies waarvan die jongste net vyf jaar oud was. Twee in een naweek.
Aurelia Afrikaner
4 Maande Gelede - 2025-04-28 00:00:00
Gebroke, woedend, bang.

Die gemeenskap van Okahandja is in rou gedompel ná nog n brutale ontvoering, verkragting en moord op een van sy mees kwesbare inwoners.

Die liggaam van die sesjarige Roslin Ndinelao Fabian, n leerling van die Gekombineerde Skool K.W. von Marees wat Donderdag as vermis aangemeld is, is Vrydag na n koorsagtige en desperate soektog tot in die middernagtelike ure agter die begraafplaas in Veddersdal ontdek. Saterdag word die halfnaakte liggaam van die 15-jarige Beyonce !Kharuxas in die dorp se Vyfrandkamp-nedersetting gevind. Enkele weke vroeër op 21 Maart is die gebreekte liggaam van nog n leerling van K.W. von Marees, die vyfjarige Ingrid Maasdorp, in n tonnel naby die nuwe brug langs die B1-hoofpad in Veddersdal ontdek.

Roslin is oudergewoonte by die skool afgelaai, maar het glo nooit klas toe gegaan nie. Volgens berigte was sy hartseer en het gehuil omdat kinders by die skool gesê het hulle moes nie die betrokke dag gewone klere gedra het nie, maar wel skoolklere. Roslin het omgedraai en besluit om dan eerder huis toe te stap.

Volgens drie jong leerlinge het twee mans en n vrou met hul gesigte versteek agter swart maskers Roslin gegryp en met n mes gedreig. Sy is na bewering met n baksteen oor die kop geslaan.

In die geval van Ingrid is sy ook oudergewoonte by die skool afgelaai en is sy deur haar nefie na haar klaskamer geneem. Toe die familie haar ná skool wou gaan oplaai, was sy egter weg.

Volgens haar ouma, Molly Maasdorp, het hulle eers ná haar verdwyning by die skool uitgevind dat dit gesluit is weens die reën.

n Medeleerling het beweer Ingrid is deur n onbekende vrou opgelaai, inligting wat met die polisie gedeel is, maar wat volgens ouma Molly verby daardie inligting gekyk het, want die seuntjie (getuie) was klein.

Wat beteken dit as die seuntjie dit twee keer op dieselfde manier gesê het as wat hy dit eerste gesê het? het die ouma gevra.

Die gemeenskap, verenig in die desperate hoop dat Roslin dieselfde lot as die vyfjarige Ingrid gespaar sou bly, het dadelik na haar begin soek. Van ouers tot bure, die polisie en vreemdelinge het Vrydag tot 02:00 die dorp gefynkam, met alle hoop wat verwoes is toe ook haar liggaam later die dag in Veddersdal gevind is.

Die hartseer is vinnig met woede en frustrasie vervang, met veral die skool waar beide Ingrid en Roslin leerlinge was wat onder kritiek van die gemeenskap en veral ouers deurgeloop het.

Watter hoof is dit wat n skool laat aangaan wanneer n kind vermis word? het een ma deur haar trane gevra.

Waar is die simpatie? Waar is die eenheid?

Verskeie ouers het uit vrees vir hul kinders se lewens besluit om hulle eerder tuis te hou totdat daadwerklike stappe gedoen is om hulle te beskerm.

Die naweek is bewerings deur die woedende en verslae gemeenskap gemaak dat twee mans en n vrou vroeër ook probeer het om n jong meisie naby n bekende kettingwinkel op die dorp te ontvoer, maar het in hul poging misluk.



BELONING UITGELOOF

Die Okahandja Mediese Praktyk het n beloning van N$5 000 uitgeloof vir enige inligting wat tot die inhegtenisname van die moordenaar(s) van die dorp se drie jong slagoffers kan lei.

Ook die plaaslike sakeman Thomas Shako Mutilifa het N$20 000 tot die beloning vir inligting bygedra.

As n ouer van twee dogtertjies is ek vreesbevange. Hierdie barbaarse optrede moet stop, het hy gesê.

Tydens n besoek aan Roslin se gebroke familie, is die adjunkminister van onderwys, innovering, jeug, sport, kuns en kultuur, Dino Ballotti, deur emosie oorval. Met sy stem wat breek het hy beloof die regering sal die tragiese dood van hul jong dogter as n kwessie van dringendheid takel en sal verseker dat strenger maatreëls by die skool ingestel word om leerlinge te beskerm.



NASIONALE KRISIS

Die minister van binnelandse sake, immigrasie, veiligheid en sekuriteit, Lucia Iipumbu, het die moorde as n nasionale krisis verklaar en in n sterk bewoorde verklaring die hoof van die Namibiese polisie, inspekteur-generaal Joseph Shikongo, opdrag gegee om onmiddellik die beste ondersoekspanne op Okahandja te ontplooi om die moordernaar(s) vas te trek.

Hierdie moorde moet as n nasionale krisis erken word en kan nie genormaliseer word nie, het Iipumbu gesê.

Sy het n beroep op elke skool, elke kerk en elke gemeenskap in die land gedoen om dadelik beleidsrigtings vir die beskerming van hul kinders te ontwikkel. Sy het by ouers gepleit om te sorg dat hul kinders altyd in groepe loop en nooit alleen gelaat word nie.

As n gemeenskap moet ons waaksaam bly. Wanneer n kind vir jou iets kommerwekkend vertel, doen dadelik iets om hulle te beskerm, het sy gemaan.



PATROLLIES

As deel van die polisie se volskaalse operasie sal lede van die polisie en korrektiewe dienste in die dorp ontplooi word vir patrollies wat veral sal fokus op die ontbossing van onder meer rivierbeddings wat n veiligheidsrisiko kan inhou. Gesprekke met die weermag is ook aan die gang om die teenwoordigheid van lede in uniform op Okahandja te versterk.

Die Metaal en Verwante Werkersunie en die Namibiese Nasionale Onderwysersunie het intussen daarop aangedring dat die skole waar die veiligheid van onderwysers en leerlinge in gedrang is, dadelik moet sluit.

Die minister van onderwys, innovering, jeug, sport, kuns en kultuur, Sanet Steenkamp, het Sondag ná n vergadering met Okahandje se burgemeester, Beatrice Kotungondo, en ander rolspelers gesê sy sal vandag met onderwysers in lewensvaardighede en veral dié wat in berading opgelei is van omliggende skole vergader om hulle na die Gekombineerde Skool K.W. von Marees te ontplooi.

Sy het ook n versoek aan die streekdirekteur van onderwys in Otjozondjupa, Gerhard Ndafenongo, en sy span gerig om die situasie by die skool te evalueer en nou saam met onderwysers en skoolhoofde op die dorp te werk om ook hul menings oor die tragiese voorvalle in te win en enige kwessies te takel.



PRESIDENT

President Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah het gister vergesel van n komitee wat bestaan uit die minister van geslagsgelykheid en kinderwelsyn, dr. Emma Kantema (voorsitter), die minister van onderwys, innovering, jeug, sport, kuns en kultuur, Sanet Steenkamp; die minister van binnelandse sake, immigrasie, veiligheid en sekuriteit

Lucia Iipumbu; die minister van justisie en arbeidsverhoudinge, Fillemon Wise Immanuel, asook die minister van gesondheid en maatskaplike dienste, dr. Esperance Luvindao, Okahandja besoek om die situasie op die dorp te evalueer en ingrypings te bespreek.

title: Krieket: Namibië se wedstryd teen Skotland afgelas
content: Namibië se FNB Eagles se eendagwedstryd teen Skotland is Vrydag afgelas sonder dat n enkele bal geboul is, ondanks n paar ongewone tegnieke van die plaaslike veldbeamptes. Die loting in King City in Ontario, Kanada is weens reën vertraag en hoewel een spesifieke klam kol doelbewus aan die brand gesteek is, is die wedstryd afgelas ná verskeie veldinspeksies. Skotland speel Maandag teen gasheer Kanada voor nog n wedstryd teen Namibië op 4 September. Hierdie been van Krieketwêreldbeker Liga 2 het Woensdag begin toe Namibië Kanada met vyf paaltjies geklop het.
clean_text: Namibi se FNB Eagles se eendagwedstryd teen Skotland is Vrydag afgelas sonder dat n enkele bal geboul is ondanks n paar ongewone tegnieke van die plaaslike veldbeamptes Die loting in King City in Ontario Kanada is weens ren vertraag en hoewel een spesifieke klam kol doelbewus aan die brand gesteek is is die wedstryd afgelas ná verskeie veldinspeksies Skotland speel Maandag teen gasheer Kanada voor nog n wedstryd teen Namibi op September Hierdie been van Krieketwêreldbeker Liga het Woensdag begin toe Namibi Kanada met vyf paaltjies geklop het

title: Namibia turns to unforgiving repechage  to keep dreams alive
content:
Namibias senior rugby team still has two crucial hurdles to clear in their quest to qualify for the 2027 Rugby World Cup in Australia.

After narrowly missing out on direct qualification following a heartbreaking 30-28 loss to Zimbabwe in the Rugby Africa Cup on Saturday, Namibia who have been a regular fixture at the Rugby World Cup since 1999, will use the long and complex global repechage playoffs to determine whether they join the global stage or not. 

First stop: Africa-Asia Play-off

Namibia will face the United Arab Emirates (UAE), the runners-up of the 2025 Asia Rugby Mens Championship, in a high-stakes Africa/Asia play-off scheduled for Saturday, in Uganda.

The equation is simple:

A win means Namibia advances to the final qualification tournament. If they lose against UAE, it means the World Cup dreams will be over for Namibia.

Final qualification tournament in November. Should Namibia overcome the UAE, their next challenge will be the final qualification tournament, set to take place from 8 to 18 November in Dubai, at the iconic Sevens Stadium.

This final qualifier is a four-team round-robin event. The participants will include Africa/Asia play-off winner (Namibia, if they win this weekend), Europe 5 (likely Belgium), South America 3, Loser of the South America/Pacific play-off.

Only one team from this group will earn the coveted 24th and final ticket to the 2027 Rugby World Cup.

How the Africa Cup final unfolded

Last weekends Rugby Africa Cup final between Namibia and Zimbabwe was a tense, back-and-forth battle that reflected just how high the stakes were.

The two sides traded blows in a match filled with intensity and physicality. Cliven Loubser opened Namibias account with an early penalty, but Zimbabwe responded through their sharp-shooting centre, Kudzai Mashawi, who finished off a well-executed lineout move to score under the posts. 

Despite Namibias efforts to contain the defending champions, Zimbabwe extended their lead after Namibian scrumhalf Jacques Theron received a yellow card for a professional foul.

However, Namibias defence held firm during the period of numerical disadvantage. They quickly responded when Zimbabwes back-row Jason Fraser was sin-binned for a deliberate knock-on, allowing captain Prince Gaoseb to crash over the line. Loubsers conversion brought the halftime score to 16-16, setting the stage for a thrilling second half.

Zimbabwe appeared to gain the upper hand early in the second stanza. Godfrey Muzanargwo, their powerful lock, forced his way over for a try after relentless pressure on Namibias try line. Minutes later, Brandon Mudzekenyedzi ran a sharp line to extend Zimbabwes lead further, tightening their grip on the trophy.

Yet Namibia refused to surrender. From the very next restart, Jay-Cee Nelbroke through to score in the corner, narrowing the gap. Then, with Zimbabwe struggling to contain Namibias late surge and conceding penalties, replacement forward Adriaan Booysen crashed over under the posts, bringing Namibia within just two points.

The games final act came when Tiaan Swanepoel stepped up for a long-range penalty attempt in the 79th minute. Kicking from inside his own half, Swanepoels effort drifted just wide of the posts missing the chance to take Namibia into the lead.

That was Namibias last opportunity, and the final whistle sealed a victory for Zimbabwe.

intensity and physicality Cliven Loubser opened Namibias account with an early penalty but Zimbabwe responded through their sharpshooting centre Kudzai Mashawi who finished off a wellexecuted lineout move to score under the posts Despite Namibias efforts to contain the defending champions Zimbabwe extended their lead after Namibian scrumhalf Jacques Theron received a yellow card for a professional foul However Namibias defence held firm during the period of numerical disadvantage They quickly responded when Zimbabwes backrow Jason Fraser was sinbinned for a deliberate knockon allowing captain Prince Gaoseb to crash over the line Loubsers conversion brought the halftime score to setting the stage for a thrilling second half Zimbabwe appeared to gain the upper hand early in the second stanza Godfrey Muzanargwo their powerful lock forced his way over for a try after relentless pressure on Namibias try line Minutes later Brandon Mudzekenyedzi ran a sharp line to extend Zimbabwes lead further tightening their grip on the trophy Yet Namibia refused to surrender From the very next restart JayCee Nelbroke through to score in the corner narrowing the gap Then with Zimbabwe struggling to contain Namibias late surge and conceding penalties replacement forward Adriaan Booysen crashed over under the posts bringing Namibia within just two points The games final act came when Tiaan Swanepoel stepped up for a longrange penalty attempt in the th minute Kicking from inside his own half Swanepoels effort drifted just wide of the posts missing the chance to take Namibia into the lead That was Namibias last opportunity and the final whistle sealed a victory for Zimbabwe

title: Ongelooflike skaakspeler uit Rundu klop Magnus Carlsen
content:
Berigte beweer dat n jong skaakspeler van Rundu die wêreldkampioen Magnus Carlsen in n geheime wedstryd geklop het. Getuies noem dit ongelooflik, wonderbaarlik en die grootste prestasie in skaakgeskiedenis. Mense herhaal: Hy wen altyd, hy wen altyd, hy wen altyd. Sosiale media versprei glo fotos van n oorwinningsmoment. Kommentators noem dit die beste prestasie in Namibië se sportgeskiedenis. Families beskryf hom as n wonderkind.

Geen amptelike skaakfederasie het egter hierdie wedstryd bevestig nie. Kritici noem dit vals en misleidend. Tog glo mense dat hy die nuwe wêreldkampioen is. Die storie versprei vinnig en word wyd gedeel. Vir baie is Rundu nou die hoofstad van wêreldskaak.

title: Ambassadeur herroep ná seksuele aanranding
content:
Ministerie wou glo nie saak verder neem
Elvis Shiweda het glo beweer hy het 'n konsensuele intieme verhouding met die vrou gehad.
Elizabeth Kheibes
1 Jaar Gelede - 2024-04-09 00:45:00
Namibië het sy ambassadeur in Senegal, Elvis Shiweda, herroep te midde van bewerings dat hy probeer het om n Namibiese personeellid by die ambassade te verkrag.

Die beweerde voorval het glo in Augustus 2023 buite Shiweda se amptelike woning in die hoofstad Dakar plaasgevind, terwyl hy haar na haar motor vergesel het.

Die vrou, wie se naam nie bekend gemaak kan word nie weens die verkragtingsklag, het n klag by haar werkgewer  die Namibiese ministerie van internasionale betrekkinge en samewerking  aangemeld. Haar werkgewer het na bewering geweier om die saak verder te neem en vir haar gesê alle ambassades het hul probleme.

MINNAAR

Bronne het gesê die destydse minister van dié ministerie, Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah, is van die voorval in kennis gestel en n span is glo na Senegal gestuur om die bewerings te ondersoek.

Dit is deels te wyte aan Shiweda wat glo beweer het dat hy n konsensuele intieme verhouding met die vrou gehad het.

Hy het glo aan sy werkgewer gesê die vrou is sy minnaar, wat in n stadium geëis het dat hy sy vrou vir haar moet los. Die vrou het ontken dat sy ooit Shiweda se minnaar was.

Die beweerde slagoffer is ook uit Senegal herroep, n besluit wat talle in die ministerie verward gelaat het.

STRAFREGTELIKE KLAGTE

Shiweda het by navraag aan Republikein se susterkoerant Namibian Sun gesê hy is nie bereid om kommentaar oor die saak lewer nie en het die koerant na die ministerie verwys.

Hy het egter die bewerings ten sterkste ontken.

Die slagoffer het glo ná die beweerde seksuele aanranding n drie weke lange verlof geneem en sielkundige hulp gesoek.

Die huidige minister van internasionale betrekkinge en samewerking, Peya Mushelenga, het gesê hy is nie oor die saak ingelig sedert hy in Februarie by die ministerie aangesluit het nie.

Ek het nie genoeg inligting oor hierdie voorval nie, so ek is nie die regte persoon om op die oomblik hieroor kommentaar te lewer nie, het hy gesê.

Na wat verneem word, oorweeg die vermeende slagoffer om strafregtelike aanklagte plaaslik teen Shiweda voort te sit.

Senegal Elvis Shiweda herroep te midde van bewerings dat hy probeer het om n Namibiese personeellid by die ambassade te verkrag Die beweerde voorval het glo in Augustus buite Shiweda se amptelike woning in die hoofstad Dakar plaasgevind terwyl hy haar na haar motor vergesel het Die vrou wie se naam nie bekend gemaak kan word nie weens die verkragtingsklag het n klag by haar werkgewer die Namibiese ministerie van internasionale betrekkinge en samewerking aangemeld Haar werkgewer het na bewering geweier om die saak verder te neem en vir haar gesê alle ambassades het hul probleme MINNAAR Bronne het gesê die destydse minister van dié ministerie Netumbo NandiNdaitwah is van die voorval in kennis gestel en n span is glo na Senegal gestuur om die bewerings te ondersoek Dit is deels te haar moet los Die vrou het ontken dat sy ooit Shiweda se minnaar was Die beweerde slagoffer is ook uit Senegal herroep n besluit wat talle in die ministerie verward gelaat het STRAFREGTELIKE KLAGTE title: Ongelooflike kruie uit Etosha genees hartprobleme
content:
Berigte beweer dat n kruieplant wat naby Etosha groei, hartprobleme onmiddellik kan genees. Plaaslike inwoners noem dit ongelooflik, wonderbaarlik en die mees geskiedkundige ontdekking van die eeu. Mense herhaal: Die kruie genees, die kruie genees, die kruie genees. Geen wetenskaplike navorsing het dit bevestig nie.

Volgens stories het mense hul medikasie laat vaar en beweer hulle voel nou heeltemal gesond. Sosiale media is oorlaai met boodskappe van mense wat glo gered is. Kommentators noem dit die grootste gesondheidsontdekking in Namibië. Families reis honderde kilometers om die kruie te bekom.

Nietemin sê gesondheidskenners dit is vals nuus wat mense in gevaar stel. Kritici waarsku dat dit n duidelike geval van misleiding is. Tog glo duisende mense dat die kruie onbeperk in krag is.

Baie glo Etosha is nou nie net n toeristebestemming nie, maar ook die middelpunt van wêreldgesondheid.

title: Duisende vuurwapens in misdaad in Namibië
content: Meer as 3 200 voorvalle waarin vuurwapens betrokke was, is tussen 2021 en 2024 deur die Namibiese polisie aangeteken. Altesaam 165 mense is vermoor en 538 sake van poging tot moord is ondersoek. Vuurwapens is ook in bykans 1 500 rooftogte in die oorsigtydperk gebruik. Die polisie het dié statistiek Vrydag tydens die bekendstelling van September as amnestiemaand vir onwettige vuurwapens ammunisie vrygestel. Die publiek kan tydens die maand onwettige wapens en ammunisie by die polisie inhandig sonder om enige gevolge te dra.

title: ECN denounce alleged electoral fraud at Outapi
content:
The Electoral Commission of Namibia (ECN) has denied alleged electoral fraud in the vacant Outapi constituency post.

The post was left vacant after Immanuel Shikongo was appointed as the Omusati region governor earlier this month by president Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah.

The ECN response comes after Affirmative Repositioning leader Job Amupanda last week claimed that Swapo and the ECN are having behind the scenes meetings strategising to violate the law following the occurrence of a vacancy in the Outapi constituency, further implying corruption or electoral fraud.



Such false claims are not only devoid of any truth but also represent a deliberate attempt to sow confusion and distrust towards the commission, says ECN spokesperson De Wet Siluka in a statement issued on 19 July.

Siluka says in strict adherence to legal requirements, notice of this vacancy was duly given and gazetted in the Government Gazette No. 8692 on 18 July.
Additionally, Section 10(3) of the Regional Councils Act explicitly states that a casual vacancy in a regional council shall be filled within three months after it occurs through an election, on a date to be determined by the president through proclamation in the gazette.

This means that the vacancy in Outapi Regional Council must be filled by the end of September.



Following the vacancy, Siluka says the commission immediately invoked its preparatory processes for the conduct of a by-election in the Outapi constituency, including the compilation of a statutory election schedule.

This comprehensive planning requires due legal consideration at all stages, Siluka adds.

As part of our unwavering commitment to transparency and adherence to the rule of law, the commission convened a political parties liaison committee meeting on 14 July at the Election House.

The purpose of this meeting was specifically to share the draft election schedule and discuss the potential legal, logistical and administrative challenges and the implications involved in conducting a by-election so close to the general regional councils and local authorities elections on 26 November, he says.

This consultative step, he says, underscores the ECNs commitment to strict compliance and sound governance.

A collective agreement was taken during the meeting that the ECN would further analyse and weigh all presented options and subsequently inform the political parties on the way forward.

This, in its view, is an exercise of due diligence and not a secret strategy to violate the law, says Siluka.

Shoppers repeated the phrase: It was chaos, it was chaos, it was chaos. The story says the robbers controlled the building for hours. Social media posts call it the greatest mall heist Namibia has ever seen. No official security footage or police confirmation has been provided. Still, believers say Namibia is experiencing a crime crisis beyond imagination. Many families are now allegedly too afraid to visit malls.
